block.p: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
Music

CHALFONTE HOTEL ''Concerts by Candlelight'' featuring Bonnie Hoke, soprano, and Georgiana Rosca, pianist. Tuesday at 8:30 p.m. in the Henry Sawyer Room. Tickets: $7, or free with dinner. ''For Me. . .Formidable!'' cabaret of French songs, featuring Jilline Ringle. Through Sept. 17. Performances are at 9 p.m. on Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday evenings. Tickets: $20; $18 for students and older people; $8 for children under 12. 301 Howard Street, Cape May. (609) 884-8409.

CHICKEN BONE BEACH Preview of next year's ''Sunset Jazz on the Beach'' concert series featuring Roy Ayers, vibraphonist, and Ubiquity, along with Hassan Abdullah and his quintet. Thursday, 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. Free. Between Missouri and Mississippi Avenues, next to the Ocean One Mall, Atlantic City. (609) 449-7126.
FAIR LAWN SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL The Bayou Dixieland Band, Alex Watkins, leader. Today at 8:30 p.m. Free. Memorial Park, Berdan Avenue, Fair Lawn. (201) 796-6746.

FREEHOLD CENTER PARTNERSHIP Kruise Nite featuring Dave Sneedon, Elvis impersonator, and Bill Turner and Blue Smoke. Thursday at 6 p.m. Benefit for the Open Door Food Pantry; donations accepted. Throckmorton Street, Freehold. (732) 946-2711.

GEORGE STREET PLAYHOUSE ''Remembering Harry Chapin,'' a live concert tribute for the late singer/songwriter. Saturday at 7 p.m. John McMenamin will perform over two hours of Chapin songs and stories. Tickets: $18 and $35; proceeds benefit World Hunger Year, the Harry Chapin Foundation and Elijah's Promise Soup Kitchen in New Brunswick. 9 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick. (732) 577-6589.

MAXWELL'S Rival School's United by Fate and J Majesty. Wednesday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $6. Plug Sparks, The Makeout Party and Ex Models. Thursday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $6. 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken. (201) 653-1703.

NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER ''Absolut Sounds of the City 2000,'' outdoor music series. Thursday evenings, 5 to 10 o'clock. Terraplane Blues; Capari Cani (Peruvian and Equadorian Wind); La Jorga (Latin Rock); Raices Habaneras. Free. Theater Square. 1 Center Street, Newark. (888) 466-5722.
NORTH WILDWOOD SUMMER SERIES The Tokens. Thursday at 8 p.m. The Impalas. Saturday at 8 p.m. Free. North Wildwood's amphitheater, Ocean and Second Avenues. Free. (609) 889-2241.

OCEAN GROVE SUMMER CONCERT SERIES Through Sept. 9. Free Organ Recitals featuring Gordon Turk, soloist. Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. Doo-Wop All-Stars, including Cornell Gunter's Coasters, The Platters, The Drifters and The Shangri-Las. Saturday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $25 (reserved); $20 (general admission). The Great Auditorium, Ocean Grove. (732) 988-0645.

PNC BANK ARTS CENTER Luther Vandross and Boyz II Men. Today at 7 p.m. Tickets: $20.25 to $60.25. D'Angela and Erykah Badu. Tuesday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $27.50 to $65. Tony Bennett and Diana Krall. Wednesday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $18 to $65. Exit 116, off the Garden State Parkway, Holmdel. (201) 507-8900.
PREMIER THEATER COMPANY Free Outdoor concert featuring a cast of more than 40 Premier performers. Saturday at 7:30 p.m. Algonquin Arts Theater, 171 Main Street, Manasquan. (732) 223-7122.
RAHWAY DIVISION OF PARKS AND RECREATION The Mayor's Concert Series featuring the Sensational Soul Cruisers. Thursday at 7 p.m. Free. West Main Street at Irving Street, Rahway. (732) 669-3600.
SCOTCH PLAINS PUBLIC LIBRARY Ebony Brass Sextet (jazz). Wednesday, 7 p.m. to 8:30 p.m. Free. 1927 Bartle Avenue, Scotch Plains. (908) 322-5007.

SHANGHAI JAZZ Wooster St. Trolley (Dixieland). Wednesday at 7 p.m. Denise Jannah, jazz. Thursday at 6:45 p.m. and 8:30 p.m. Rio Clemente, pianist. Friday at 6:45 p.m. and 8:30 p.m. Dan Crisci and Bill Robinson Quartet perform Nat King Cole favorites. Saturday at 6:30 p.m. and 8:45 p.m. No cover. 24 Main Street, Madison. (973) 822-2899.
SOMERSET COUNTY PARK COMMISSION Diane Schuur, jazz. Tonight at 7 p.m. Free. Duke Island Park bandshell, across from Visitor's Center. (908) 722-1200, ext. 351.
STANHOPE HOUSE Ron Levy's Wild Kingdom, blues. Today at 8 p.m. Tickets: $7. Foxtrot Zulu. Thursday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $7. 45 Main Street, Stanhope. (973) 347-0458.
TIERNEY'S TAVERN Diane Moser's Composers Big Band, featuring Scott Reeves, composer and trombonist. Wednesday, 8 p.m. to 11 p.m. Cover: $7. 136 Valley Road, Montclair. (973) 744-9785.
Theater

BANANAS COMEDY CLUB Ted Alexandro, along with Andrew Goffman and Ramu. Friday and Saturday at 9:30 p.m. Tickets: $10 on Friday; $12 on Saturday. Holiday Inn, 283 Route 17 South, Hasbrouck Heights. (201) 727-1090.

CENTENARY STAGE COMPANY ''Pippin'' and ''Into the Woods,'' as part of the Young Performers Workshop Summer Festival of Shows. Today at 2 p.m. (Pippin) and 5 p.m. (Into the Woods). Tickets: $8; $6 for children under 12. Centenary College, 400 Jefferson Street, Hackensack. (908) 979-0900.

EATONTOWN PLAYHOUSE ''Three Murders and It's Only Monday,'' murder mystery comedy spoof. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $16; $10 for students and older people. 37 Highway 35 North, Tower Shopping Center, Eatontown. (732) 460-0100.
HUDSON SHAKESPEARE COMPANY ''Much Ado About Nothing.'' Tomorrow at 7 p.m. Free. Frank Sinatra Park, between 4th and 5th Streets, Hoboken. (201) 420-2207.

HUNTERDON HILLS PLAYHOUSE ''Razzmatazz,'' musical celebrating popular songs of the 20th century. Through Sept. 9 Monday through Saturday luncheon matinees beginning at 11 a.m.; Saturdays at 6:30 p.m.; Sundays at 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $39.50 to $51 (includes show and lunch/dinner). Exit 12 off Routes 78 and 22, Perryville. (800) 447-7313.
LUMIA THEATER ''Amnesia Wars.'' Friday and Saturday, Sept. 8 and 9 at 8 p.m.; Sept. 15 and 16, 10 p.m. Tickets: $10. 179 Broadway, Long Branch. (732) 229-3166.
LUMIA THEATER -- STAGE II Carson Grace Becker's ''A Mislaid Heaven,'' staged reading. Tomorrow at 2 p.m. and 7 p.m. Tickets: $7.50. 179 Broadway, Long Branch. (732) 229-3166.
NEW JERSEY SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL ''Rhinoceros.'' Today at 2 p.m. Tickets: $21 to $38. F. M. Kirby Shakespeare Theater, 36 Madison Avenue, Madison. (973) 408-5600.

PLAYS IN THE PARK ''You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown.'' Through Thursday. Performances every night at 8:30 p.m. except Sundays. Tickets: $3; free for children 12 and under. Stephen J. Capestro Theater, Roosevelt Park, off of Route 1 South, Edison. (732) 548-2884.
RITZ THEATER ''Geist, Contemporary Vaudevillianism!'' Today at 2 p.m. Tickets: $12.50. 915 White Horse Pike, Oaklyn. (609) 858-5230.
Music and Galleries

ABC GALLERY ''The Fruits of My Labor, Oil Paintings and Pastels by Fern Blumberg.'' Through Sept. 29. Hours: Mondays and Thursdays, 1 to 9 p.m.; Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 p.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Lambertville Public Library, 6 Lilly Street, Lambertville. (609) 397-0275.

AFRICAN ART MUSEUM OF THE S.M.A. FATHERS ''Eloquent Threads: The Language of African Costumes and Textiles.'' Through Dec. 31. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 23 Bliss Avenue, Tenafly. (201) 894-8611.

AMERICAN LABOR MUSEUM ''9th Annual Grand Parade'' celebrating the American worker. Next Sunday at 1:30 p.m. Step off will be at the museum and the two mile march will end at the Great Falls, Paterson. ''Workers' Portraits,'' photodocumentary exhibit by Robert Gumpert. Through Dec. 31. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; other times by appointment. Botto House National Landmark, 83 Norwood Street, Haledon. (973) 595-7953.

BRION GALLERIES ''Alien Beings of Uncertain Origin,'' one-man show of monotypes by Stephen McKenzie. Through today. ''Impressions of New Jersey: Beauty, Botany and Everyday People of the Garden State.'' ''Visions in Mexico: Oil Paintings by Nina Wisniewski.'' Through Sept. 24. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. 1293 Route 179, Lambertville. (609) 397-7030.

CAMDEN COUNTY CULTURAL AND HERITAGE COMMISSION ''Home Traditions,'' an exhibition of domestic artifacts crafted by New Jersey folk artists. Bobbie Diamond Adams exhibition of mixed media painting and prints. James Cicalese exhibition of photographs. Through Sept. 8. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. and 2 to 4 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 4 p.m. Hopkins House, 250 South Park Drive, Haddon Township. (609) 858-0040.
CHAMOT GALLERY ''From Pop to the Millennium: 40 Years of Bill Barrell.'' Through Sept. 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. 111 First Street, Jersey City. (201) 610-1468.

DRUE CHRYST GALLERY Elaine Kurie, oil still lifes and landscapes. Friday through Sept. 30. Opening reception: Friday, 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; or by appointment. 21 White Deer Plaza, Lake Mohawk, Sparta. (973) 729-0609.

GROUNDS FOR SCULPTURE ''Summer 2000 Exhibition.'' Through Sept. 10. Hours: Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Tuesday and Wednesday by appointment. 18 Fairgrounds Road, Hamilton Township. (609) 586-0616.

HUNTERDON MUSEUM OF ART Lyanne Malamed, paintings and drawings. Through Sept. 10. ''Four Points of View: Artists From Lambertville.'' Through Sept. 10. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. 7 Lower Center Street, Clinton. (908) 735-8415.

J.C.C. ON THE PALISADES ''Exploring Collage,'' exhibition by Naomi Kahan, a Ridgewood artist. Through Tuesday. ''Yemenite Jews: The Last Generation'' photographic exhibition. Thursday through Sept. 29. Hours: Monday through Thursday, 9 a.m to 10 p.m.; Friday and Sunday, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. 411 East Clinton Avenue, Tenafly. (201) 569-7900, extension 433.

JERSEY CITY MUSEUM ''The Prints of a Sculptor,'' by Melvin Edwards. Through Oct. 7. Hours: Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Wednesdays, 10:30 a.m.to 8 p.m. 472 Jersey Avenue, Jersey City. (201) 547-4514.

LONG BEACH ISLAND FOUNDATION OF THE ARTS AND SCIENCES ''Foundation Faculty Exhibition.'' Through Sept. 6. ''2000 Craft Gallery.'' Through Oct. 15. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. 120 Long Beach Boulevard, Loveladies. (609) 494-1241, extension 300.

MERCER COUNTY COMMUNITY COLLEGE ''Narrative Stance,'' exhibition of two Mercer County artists, Loring Hughes of Lawrenceville and Thomas Kelly of Trenton. Tuesday through Sept. 28. Hours: Mondays, 12:30 to 3 p.m.; Tuesdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Wednesdays and Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. and 6 to 8 p.m. The Gallery, Communications Center, 1200 Old Trenton Road, Trenton. (609) 586-4800, extension 3588.

MONTCLAIR ART MUSEUM ''Croquet: The Art of Play.' Through Oct. 15. Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 7 p.m.; Sept. 9 through Oct. 15, course will be open Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $4 for children. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $4 for older people and students; free for members and children under 12. 3 South Mountain Avenue, Montclair. (973) 746-5555.

MORRIS COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''1900,'' exhibit of photos, products and objects. Through September. Hours: Mondays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students. Acorn Hall, 68 Morris Avenue, Morristown. (973) 267-3465.

MORRIS MUSEUM New Jersey Arts Annual: ''Everything for the Home'' juried exhibition. Through Nov. 17. ''A Collector's Vision: Selections From the Collections of Edmund W. Pease and Nurak Israsena.'' Through Sept. 17. Hours: Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for older people and children under age 3. 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown. (973) 538-0454.
NABISCO GALLERY ''Alchemy: Society of Layerists in Multi-Media.'' Through Sept. 6. Hours: daily, noon to 4 p.m. 100 DeForest Avenue, East Hanover. (973) 503-2000.

NEW JERSEY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''Dining In, Dining Out,'' featuring photographs, video clips, rare silverware, period furniture and 18th-century cookbooks. Through summer 2001. ''Pride of Newark: Baseball's Bears and Eagles,'' about the history of baseball in Newark. Through summer 2001. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 52 Park Place, Newark. (973) 596-8500.

NEW JERSEY STATE MUSEUM ''Leah Phyfer Sloshberg Collection of Fine Art.'' Through Sept. 3. ''The Art of Jack Delano.'' Through Sept. 4. ''Of Rock and Fire.'' On extended view. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 4:45 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Free. 205 West State Street, Trenton. (609) 292-6464.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''Katherine Choy: A Promise Unfulfilled'' ceramic showcase. Wednesday through Jan. 7. ''Wetlands.'' Through Sept. 17. ''2000 New Jersey Fine Arts Annual: Into the Millennium.'' Through Sept. 17. ''The Luminous Image, V,'' and exhibition of illuminated photography. Through Oct. 8. ''Year of the Dragon: The Calligraphy of Wang Fangyu.'' Through Nov. 12. ''Needless Necessity: Jewelry, Silver and Personal Meaning.'' Through December. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; Thursdays (after hours) until 8:30 p.m. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6550.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - NEWARK ''Carrie Yamaoka: New Paintings.'' Friday through Oct. 13. Robeson Center Art Gallery, 350 Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd, Newark. Hours: Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 4 p.m. (973) 353-5119, ext. 32. Prints and Drawings by Anaida Hernandez, 1989-1999. Through September. Hours: Monday through Thursday, 8 a.m. to midnight; Friday, 8 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 10 p.m. Dana Library, 185 University Avenue, Newark. (973) 353-5900.

TRENTON CITY MUSEUM ''TAWA (Trenton Artists Workshop Association) Two Thousand.'' Through Sept. 24. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Sundays, 2 to 4 p.m. Ellarslie, Cadwalader Park, Trenton. (609) 989-3632.

WHEATON VILLAGE ''American Glass: 1900-2000,'' featuring more than 100 industrial and decorative pieces. Through Oct. 22. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $6 for older people; $3.50 for students. No admission charge to the Gallery of American Craft. Exit 26, Route 55, Millville. (800) 998-4552, extension 2756.
For Children

MORRIS COUNTY PARK COMMISSION ''Swamp Walk.'' Friday at 9:30 a.m. ''Night Walk at the Swamp.'' Saturday at 7 p.m. Free. Pre-registration is required. Great Swamp Outdoor Education Center, 247 Southern Boulevard, Chatham Township. (973) 635-6629.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''Where in the Universe Is Carmen Sandiego?'' at the Alice and Leonard Dreyfuss Planetarium. Through October. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays at 2:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 p.m. and 3 p.m. Tickets: $3; $2 for members; $1 for children and older people. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6355.
OCEAN COUNTY ARTISTS' GUILD ''Cartoon Demo'' by Paul Pugliese. Wednesday at 7 p.m. Free. Ocean and Chestnut Avenues, Island Heights. (732) 270-3111.

TRAILSIDE NATURE AND SCIENCE CENTER Planetarium Show. Today and next Sunday at 2 p.m. and 3:30 p.m. Fee: $3; $2.55 for older people. ''Lake Surprise Stroll.'' Next Sunday at 2 p.m. Donations accepted. Pre-registration is required. 452 New Providence Road, Mountainside. (908) 789-3670.
Spoken Word

BARNES & NOBLE Barbara Kessel, author, will discuss and sign her book ''Suddenly Jewish: Jews Raised as Gentiles Discover their Jewish Roots.'' Wednesday at 8 p.m. 395 Route 3E, Clifton. (973) 779-2730.

HOBOKEN HISTORICAL MUSEUM ''History You Can Eat!'' lecture on heirloom vegetables by Joseph Cavanaugh, the director of the Garden State Heirloom Society. Today at 2 p.m. The First Annual Heirloom Tomato-Tasting Festival will follow the lecture. Shipyard space at 13th and Hudson Streets, Hoboken. (201) 656-2240.

NEW JERSEY CITY UNIVERSITY Karen DeAngelis, director of the Women's Center of New Jersey City University, will speak on ''Women Returning to School.'' Wednesday, noon to 1 p.m. Women's Center, 32 College Street, Jersey City. (201) 200-3189.
Etc.
CAPE MAY COUNTY HISTORICAL MUSEUM CLAMBAKE Today, 4 p.m. to 8 p.m. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. 4-H Fairgrounds, 355 Court House-South Dennis Roat (Rt. 657), Cape May Court House. (609) 463-1880.

ENGLEWOOD PUBLIC LIBRARY ''Wednesday Night Comedy Film Festival.'' Through August. ''Being John Malkovich.'' Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. Seating is limited to 65 people. 31 Engle Street, Englewood. (201) 568-2215, ext. 244.
HISTORIC COLD SPRING VILLAGE Saturday Evening Concert Series. Bob Ferris Orchestra. Saturday at 6:30 p.m. Village Gazebo. Free. 720 Route 9, three miles north of Cape May City. (609) 898-2300.

OCEAN COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY 16th Annual Ole Time Antiques and Collectibles Faire. Includes more than 100 vendors, antiques and collectibles. Saturday, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. Free. 26 Hadley Avenue, Toms River. (732) 341-1880.
PASSAIC PUBLIC LIBRARY Meet ''Sly the Silver Fox,'' the mascot of the New York Nets. Tomorrow, 6 p.m. to 7 p.m. Free. 195 Gregory Avenue. Passaic. (973) 779-0474.

PEQUEST TROUT HATCHERY AND NATURAL RESOURCE EDUCATION CENTER ''Fly Fishing for Beginners.'' Topics include equipment, knot tying, entomology, stream tactics and casting techniques. Today at 10 a.m. For ages 12 and up. Pre-registration required. 605 Pequest Road, Oxford. (908) 637-4125.
WEIS ECOLOGY CENTER Appalachian Trail Hike. Today, 9:30 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. Cost: $5. Pre-registration required. 150 Snake Den Road, Ringwood. (973) 835-2160.
At the Casinos
All tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.
ATLANTIC CITY HILTON Everly Brothers. Today at 8 p.m. Tickets: $40 and $45. Grand Theater, Boston and Pacific Avenues. (609) 340-7200.

BALLY'S PARK PLACE ''Legends in Concert,'' impersonations of Stevie Wonder, Little Richard, Elvis Presley, Linda Ronstadt and Barbara Streisand. Mondays through Thursdays at 3:30 and 7:30 p.m.; Saturdays at 8 and 10:30 p.m.; Sundays at 7:30 and 10 p.m. Tickets: $15 to $25. Park Cabaret, Boardwalk and Park Place. (800) 225-5977.
CAESARS ATLANTIC CITY The Beach Boys. Today at 8 p.m. Tickets: $50. Circus Maximus Theater, 2100 Pacific Avenue. (800) 677-7469.

CLARIDGE HOTEL ''Pump Boys and Dinettes,'' national tour of the Broadway musical. Through Sept. 24. Performances are Mondays through Thursdays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 9 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. and 7 p.m. Tickets: $15, Sundays through Thursdays; $19, Saturdays. Palace Theater, Boardwalk and Park Place. (609) 340-3700.

SANDS HOTEL AND CASINO 50th Anniversary of Rock 'n' Roll. Today at 4:30 p.m. and 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $32.50. JoDee Messina. Thursday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $37.50. Jerry Blavat. Thursday, 5 p.m. to 7 p.m. Bud Noble. Wednesday through next Sunday, 6 p.m. to 10 p.m. Beth Ciotta Trio. Wednesday through next Sunday, 10:15 p.m. to 2:15 a.m. Copa Lounge. Free. The Diamonds. Through Sept. 7. Call for times. Tickets: $15. Cozy Morley. Tuesday and Wednesday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $15. Indiana Avenue and Brighton Park. (609) 441-4137.

TROPICANA Randy Travis in Concert. Friday at 9 p.m.; Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $55 (Friday and Sunday orchestra); $45 (Friday and Sunday mezzanine); $30 (Friday and Sunday balcony); $60 (Saturday orchestra); $50 (Saturday mezzanine); $35 (Saturday balcony). Latin Fever Revue. Through Sept. 21. Call for times. Tickets: $9.90. ''Titanic: The Return,'' all new exhibition with more than 250 artifacts. Through Sept. 9. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. Tickets: $14.95; $6.95 for children, ages 5 to 11. Grand Exhibition Center, fourth floor, South Tower. Boardwalk and Brighton Avenue. (609) 340-4020.

TRUMP MARINA Shawn Wayans. Next Sunday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $30 and $40. Grand Cayman. Taj Mahal Phantom Blues Band. Wednesday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25. The Shell. Huron Avenue and Brigantine Boulevard. (800) 777-8477.

TRUMP PLAZA ''Dancin' in the Streets,'' a song and dance block party. Monday and Thursday at 4 p.m.; Tuesday through Thursday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $18; $12 for matinees. Boardwalk at Mississippi Avenue. (800) 759-8786.
TRUMP TAJ MAHAL Dwight Yoakam. Saturday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $36.50 and $42.50. Xanadu. 1000 Boardwalk. (609) 449-1000.

An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. Doo-Wop All-Stars, including Cornell Gunter's Coasters, The Platters, The Drifters and The Shangri-Las. Saturday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $25 (reserved); $20 (general admission). The Great Auditorium, Ocean Grove. (732) 988-0645.

PNC BANK ARTS CENTER Luther Vandross and Boyz II Men. Today at 7 p.m. Tickets: $20.25 to $60.25. D'Angela and Erykah Badu. Tuesday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $27.50 to $65. Tony Bennett and Diana Krall. Wednesday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $18 to $65. Exit 116, off the Garden State Parkway, Holmdel. (201) 507-8900.

RAHWAY DIVISION OF PARKS AND RECREATION The Mayor's Concert Series featuring the Sensational Soul Cruisers. Thursday at 7 p.m. Free. West Main Street at Irving Street, Rahway. (732) 669-3600.

Friday at 6:45 p.m. and 8:30 p.m. Dan Crisci and Bill Robinson Quartet perform Nat King Cole favorites. Saturday at 6:30 p.m. and 8:45 p.m. No cover. 24 Main Street, Madison. (973) 822-2899.

STANHOPE HOUSE Ron Levy's Wild Kingdom, blues. Today at 8 p.m. Tickets: $7. Foxtrot Zulu. Thursday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $7. 45 Main Street, Stanhope. (973) 347-0458.

Theater
